questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

It is an important structure as it overlies the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere. The bone in this area is thin and any injury to this area may lead to rupture of the middle meningeal artery leading to extradural hematoma.

questions.text: Phases of the ventricular muscle action potential are shown below. At which phase is the action potential most dependent on sodium permeability?
questions.solution:
The action potential is most dependant on sodium permeability in phase 0. 

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had a history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun, severe freckling in the sun-exposed areas. The autosomal recessive condition responsible for this is due to:
questions.solution:
The image shows a girl with Xeroderma Pigmentosum. It is characterized by Defective Nucleotide Excision repair that is transmitted autosomal recessively

Clinical Features:

Typical 3 stage Progression.

Child is asymptomatic at birth. Diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle like areas over the sun exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.

Poikiloderma is a characteristic feature of the second stage. Poikiloderma results in skin atrophy, telangiectasias with mottled hyperpigmentation and hypopigmentation.

In the third stage appearance of cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Related Pearl: Important DNA Repair Disorders Associated with Cutaneous Features

Disorder

DNA Repair Defect

Xeroderma pigmentosum

Nucleotide excision repair

Cockayne syndrome

Nucleotide excision repair

Trichothiodystrophy

Nucleotide excision repair

Rothmund–Thomson syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Bloom syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Werner syndrome

Recombination Q helicase

Ataxia telangiectasia

Double strand break repair

Fanconi anaemia

Interstrand cross‐link repair

Muir–Torre syndrome

Mismatch repair

questions.text: The peripheral blood smear picture of a patient with Acute Promyelocytic Leukaemia is given in the image. The cell indicated by the arrow is best described as:
questions.solution:
The given cell shows multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell resembling a bundle of sticks. Such cells have been termed as “Faggot cells” (faggot in French means bundle of sticks).  
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is a tumour of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APML) belongs to FAB M3 class.

Numerous Auer rods which are azurophilic granules are present in bundles with individual progranulocytes. Primary granules are very prominent associated with very high incidence of DIC. They are myeloperoxidase (+); cytogenetic abnormality seen in APML is t(15;17)(q22;q12). These AML cells express CD13 & CD 33 antigens.

Other options:

  • The term flaming promyelocyte has been coined to describe cells that appear to be “breaking apart”, taking on a vibrant reddish-purple hue with the apparent liberation of granules into the surrounding cellular matrix.
  • Promyelocytes containing fine granules appear “dusky” or “hazy” and are referred to as such.
  • Buttocks cells are cells having a notched appearance that are found in certain malignancies such as, 

                                               - Non Hodgkin's lymphoma

                                               - Sezary syndrome

                                               - Mycosis fungoides

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia

The WHO system divides acute myeloid leukemia (AML) into several groups:

AML with certain genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes)

  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 8 and 21 [t(8;21)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 16 [t(16;16) or inv(16)]
  • APL with the PML-RARA fusion gene
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 9 and 11 [t(9;11)]
  • AML with a translocation between chromosomes 6 and 9 [t(6:9)]
  • AML with a translocation or inversion in chromosome 3 [t(3;3) or inv(3)]
  • AML (megakaryoblastic) with a translocation between chromosomes 1 and 22 [t(1:22)]
  • AML with the BCR-ABL1 (BCR-ABL) fusion gene*
  • AML with mutated NPM1 gene
  • AML with biallelic mutations of the CEBPA gene (that is, mutations in both copies of the gene)
  • AML with mutated RUNX1 gene*

*This is still a "provisional entity," meaning it is not yet clear if there's enough evidence that it is a unique group.

AML with myelodysplasia-related changes

AML related to previous chemotherapy or radiation

AML not otherwise specified (This includes cases of AML that do not fall into one of the above groups and is similar to the FAB classification.)

  • AML with minimal differentiation (FAB M0)
  • AML without maturation (FAB M1)
  • AML with maturation (FAB M2)
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukemia (FAB M4)
  • Acute monoblastic/monocytic leukemia (FAB M5)
  • Pure erythroid leukemia (FAB M6)
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (FAB M7)
  • Acute basophilic leukemia
  • Acute panmyelosis with fibrosis

Myeloid sarcoma (also known as granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma)

Myeloid proliferations related to Down syndrome

Undifferentiated and biphenotypic acute leukemias are not strictly AML, but are leukemias that have both lymphocytic and myeloid features. They are sometimes called mixed phenotype acute leukemias (MPALs).

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on the principle of:
questions.solution:
The above image shows a HbsAg card test kit which works on the principle of immunochromatography.

The immunochromatographic membrane is used for antigen detection, while a nitrocellulose membrane is used to absorb the antigen from a specimen. A coloured reaction appears directly on the membrane with the sequential addition of conjugate followed by the substrate. In some cases, the antigen is captured by a bound antibody directed against the antigen. These assays have the advantage of being rapid and also frequently include a built-in internal control.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones act through the receptor shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The receptor in the given image uses tyrosine kinase signaling. Insulin acts through this receptor to exert its functions.

Other hormones acting via tyrosine kinase signaling: 

  • Growth hormone
  • Growth factors like VEGF, PDGF, FGF, NGF
  • Prolactin
  • Leptin

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A and D
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
 
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Parathyroid hormone
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through JAK-STAT or MAP kinase pathway Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Note: Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

questions.text: Identify the injury in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows abrasion.

An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and, in the most restrictive of definitions, is one that does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.

Thus the pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. Because of the corrugated nature of the dermal papillae, however, many abrasions enter the corium and bleeding commonly occurs.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
questions.solution:
The image depicts laryngeal papilloma.

Laryngeal papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis)

  • It is the most common benign neoplasm of the larynx in children.
  • It is caused by HPV 6 and 11. 
  • Involves supraglottic and glottic regions of larynx.
  • Clinical features:
    • Age 3–5 years
    • Hoarseness or aphonia
    • Respiratory difficulty
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. 
  • Treatment consists of microlaryngoscopy and CO2 laser Excision.

Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female complaining of irritation in her left eye has the following finding. Which of the following condition commonly causes this?
questions.solution:
The clinical condition and the given image is suggestive of scleromalacia perforans. It is commonly associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Scleromalacia perforans is a specific type of progressive scleral thinning without inflammation. It is typically seen in elderly women with longstanding rheumatoid arthritis. Despite the term 'scleromalacia perforans', perforation is extremely rare as the integrity is maintained by a thin layer of fibrous tissue.

Overall, 50% of cases of scleritis are associated with systemic diseases; the most common being connective tissue diseases. About 0.5% of patients suffering from seropositive rheumatoid arthritis develop scleritis.

Other associated collagen disorders are as follows:

  • Wegener’s granulomatosis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Relapsing polychondritis

questions.text: The following image represents
questions.solution:
Option a: Rashtriya swasthya bima yojana

Option c: Integrated child development services

Option d: Mission indradhanush

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given in question illustrates the life cycle of the Nipah virus, an RNA virus. Fruit bats serve as its natural host, and transmission occurs from bats and pigs to humans.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus from the family Paramyxoviridae and the genus Henipavirus. It is zoonotic, with fruit bats from the Pteropodidae family as its natural hosts. Transmission occurs from animals, such as bats and pigs, to humans, as well as between humans.Symptoms range from asymptomatic (subclinical) infection to acute respiratory illness and fatal encephalitis.

Currently, no treatment or vaccine exists for humans or animals, and supportive care is the main form of treatment for those infected. Nipah virus is also listed among the WHO's Blueprint priority diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Japanese encephalitis : Humans serve as dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui, commonly found in India. The transmission cycle involves birds, mosquitoes, and humans.The JE virus also infects various non-human hosts, such as pigs and birds like pond herons.

The main transmission cycles are:
(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig
(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Herons act as reservoir hosts, while pigs function as amplifier hosts. Control measures focus on mosquito control, relocating pig farms away from human habitation, and vaccinating pigs.

Option B: Zika virus is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito (Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus).

Anyone who lives in or travels to a region with risk of Zika infection, and has not already been infected with Zika virus can get it from mosquito bites. Once a person has been infected, they are likely to be protected from future infections

A pregnant woman can pass Zika virus to her fetus during pregnancy. Zika is a cause of microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Zika virus has also been found in breast milk. Possible Zika virus infections have been identified in breastfeeding babies, but Zika virus transmission through breast milk has not been confirmed.
Zika can be passed through sexual intercourse, even if the infected person does not have symptoms at the time.
To date, there have not been any confirmed blood transfusion transmission cases in the United States. There are reports of laboratory acquired Zika virus infections, although the route of transmission was not clearly established in all cases
 

Option D: Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.

questions.text: Identify the English epidemiologist in the picture below:
questions.solution:
John Snow

  • English epidemiologist; studied cholera and its association with polluted drinking water
  • Father of (Modern) Epidemiology
  • Often called as ‘Greatest Doctor’
  • Calculated dose of ether and chloroform as surgical anesthesia

questions.text: The flow-volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is ________
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in patient 1 with restrictive pattern on flow-volume curve is Myasthenia gravis.

The flow volume curve above (patient 1) shows decreased Total lung capacity, Vital capacity, Residual volume. Hence, the loop shifts towards the right. This is seen in restrictive lung disease.

Myasthenia gravis presents with ventilatory restriction due to reduced respiratory muscle strength.

Asthma, emphysema, endobronchial neoplasm present with obstructive flow pattern. The increased total lung capacity, vital capacity and residual volume will shift the flow volume loop to left.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with complaints of severe pain in her left great toe. The pain started since she woke up in the morning and severe to an extent that she is not able to stamp her foot on the ground. A local examination of her foot is given in the image below. Which of the following investigations is least useful in arriving at a diagnosis?

choices.text: Needle aspiration of the synovial fluid

questions.solution:
The symptoms and the clinical examination findings are suggestive of an acute attack of gout. Serum uric acid level is least useful in arriving at a diagnosis of gout.

During an acute attack of gout, the inflammatory cytokines promote the excretion of uric acid and hence, its level can be normal or decreased at such instances. This limits the use of serum uric acid level for the diagnosis of gout.

Even if the diagnosis of gout is clinically strong, it should ideally be confirmed by needle aspiration of the involved joint. The synovial fluid aspirated from the inflamed joints has the following features

  • Needle shaped monosodium urate (MSU) crystals which appear brightly birefringent with negative elongation under polarised microscopy.
  • The leukocyte counts are elevated from 2000 to 60,000/μL and give a cloudy appearance of the aspirated fluid

Ultrasound may aid in the earlier diagnosis by showing a double contour sign overlying the articular cartilage.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. Which of the following conditions is/are associated with this lesion?
  1. Chronic liver disease
  2. Pregnancy
  3. Scleroderma
  4. Thyrotoxicosis
  5. Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi (nevus araneus). They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
  • Thyrotoxicosis

They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the centre outward.

questions.text: A patient with acute hepatitis B has recovered from the infection. Identify the serological marker marked in the image:
questions.solution: The serological marker marked in the image is anti-Hbc Ab antibody. It remains elevated for a long period after recovery from infection.

questions.text: Identify the incision for appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
• Lanz incision is a transverse or skin crease incision for appendicitis,2 cm below the  umbilicus, centred on the midclavicular–midinguinal line
  • Rockey–Davis incision : Transverse right lower quadrant incision.
  • Gridiron incision : Oblique muscle splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. Also called as Mc Burney incision.
  • Rutherford–Morrison incision : oblique muscle cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary (shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

questions.text: A woman came with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the left breast. On examination, the breast appears as shown below. Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable with fixed axillary nodes on the right side. What is the most appropriate tumor staging?
questions.solution:
TNM staging in the given scenario is T4b N3c M1. 

  • Tumour of any size with overlying skin involvement (Peau d'orange appearance) - T4b
  • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement - N3c
  • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates distant metastasis - M1

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text: The operating surgeon performed the following suture technique on the skin after appendicectomy surgery. This is called_______.
questions.solution:
This suture technique is called mattress suture. The type of mattress suture performed is horizontal mattress suture. It is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edge of the wound and moving horizontally and traverse once again both the edge of the wound and tie the knot.

Other options :

B) The subcuticular suture technique is performed by taking a bite alternatively on either side of the wound and gently pulling simultaneously until the end.

C)Continuous suture technique is performed by inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and then crossing both the edges of the wound, this is performed continuously till the end is reached.

D) Interrupted suture technique is performed inserting a needle perpendicular to the incision and crossing both the edge of the wound and the knot is tied.

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

Type of Fistula

Course

 

 

 

Begins from

Ends in

Inter-sphincteric

45%

Perianal abscess

Dentate line

Inter-sphincteric space

Perianal skin or perineum

Trans- sphincteric

30%

Ischiorectal Fossa abscess

Dentate line

Via internal and external sphincters to ischio-rectal fossa

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

20%

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Inter-sphincteric space, upwards to a point above the pubo-rectalis and downwards lateral to the external anal sphincter to the ischio-rectal fossa

Perineal skin or perineum

5%

Penetrating injury

Crohn’s disease

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with the following fetal presentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of frank breech.

Breech presentation can be divided into the following:

  • Incomplete: Breech with extended legs, footling, knee presentation
  • Complete: Breech with flexed legs
Breech type Description Presenting part
Frank breech
(with extended legs)		 Thighs flexed on the trunk, legs extended at the knee joint. Buttocks and genitalia
Footling Both thighs and legs are partially extended Foot 
Knee  Thighs extended, Knee flexed Knee
Complete/flexed Both thighs and legs are flexed. Buttocks, genitalia, foot

questions.text: A 55 year old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. Hysterectomy was performed and the following specimen was  retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The specimen is of a Leiomyoma.

The uterine body / corpus is enlarged and deformed. The cut surface shows multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, white-greyish with a whorled appearance formed by the intersecting bundles of brown muscle fibers and white fibrous tissue. Leiomyomas can also present bleeding areas, cystic degeneration and calcifications. The uterine cavity is compressed.

questions.text: Identify the contraceptive shown in the given image.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a female condom. It consists of a pouch made of polyurethane which is 17 cm in length with flexible ring at each end. The inner ring at the closed end is smaller than the outer ring.

The inner ring is inserted at the apex of the vagina and the outer ring remains outside. It covers the cervix, entire vagina, and external genitalia. Hence, it provides protection against HIV and STDs. It has a failure rate of 5–15 per 100 woman-years, which is higher than that of a male condom.

questions.text: An infant weighing 4 Kg at birth is shown in the image below. The affected cranial nerves are:
questions.solution:
The infant has Erb's palsy, caused by injury to C5 and C6 nerves.

The characteristic position consists of adduction and internal rotation of the arm with pronation of the forearm. Brachial plexus injuries are common in big babies due to shoulder dystocia during birth.

Klumpke’s paralysis (image below) is caused by injury to the C7, C8 and T1 nerve roots. The baby lies with the forearm supinated and the elbow flexed. There may be a unilateral Horner’s syndrome, characterized by ipsilateral ptosis and miosis (Horner syndrome) if the sympathetic fibers of the 1st thoracic root are also injured.

questions.text: What is the procedure being performed?
questions.solution:
The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia.

The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation. So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable within 1 min. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest)

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:
questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Intracranial haemorrhage

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient comes to the OPD with a history significant for a mood disorder. Her moods can be charted as done in the image given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing 4 episodes of depression and 2 episodes of mania within 1 year, points towards a diagnosis of rapid cycling bipolar disorder. 

It is diagnosed when the patient has 4 or more episodes of depression and/or mania or hypomania within one year. There must be less than 2 weeks of normalcy between the episodes or an immediate shift between the symptoms with no intervening normal mood.

Risk factors:

  • Female patients
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Alcoholism or substance abuse
  • Antidepressants (if used without mood stabilizers)
  • Cyclothymia
  • Bipolar II disorder

The drug of choice for rapid cycling disorder is valproate. 

Note: If the phases of mania and depression alternate very rapidly in a matter of hours or days then the condition is known as ultra-rapid cycling disorder.

questions.text: The most common complication of the following procedure is_____
questions.solution:
• The image shown above is the technique of retrobulbar block which is a regional anesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery which involves the injection of a local anesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction and middle third of the orbit.
  • Complications of retrobulbar block include:
    • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
    • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
    • Proptosis
    • Perforation of the globe
    • Optic nerve atrophy
    • Oculocardiac reflex
    • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
    • Trigeminal nerve block
    • Respiratory arrest
    • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)
  • Contraindications of retrobulbar block:
    • Bleeding disorders(because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
    • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)

questions.text: What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Becker's naevus.

It is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It is often hairy. The onset is around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest.

A triad of features can be seen:

  1. Hyperpigmentation
  2. Hypertrichosis
  3. Acne

Option A: Mongolian spots are slate blue areas in the lumbosacral region that spontaneously regress before puberty.

Option B: Naevus of Ito is unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular distribution. It is not known to have hypertrichosis or acne.

Option C: Congenital melanocytic nevi are common moles that become raised and have a cerebriform appearance and can be hairy. They can occur anywhere.

questions.text: The clinical application of the effect shown below is -
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced for protons. Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

Protons and the Bragg peak effect:

The Bragg curve plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm. The proton is very fast when it enters the patient’s body and deposits only a small dose on its way. The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak. The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.
